message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the digital rectal examination findings suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Terazosin is an alpha-blocker commonly used to treat BPH by relaxing the smooth muscles in the prostate and bladder neck, improving urine flow and reducing urinary frequency. Phenoxybenzamine is used to treat hypertension caused by pheochromocytoma. Tamsulosin is also used to treat BPH but is more selective for the alpha-1A receptor subtype, which is predominately found in the prostate. Alpha-methyldopa is a centrally acting antihypertensive medication, but is not commonly used for BPH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and the enlarged prostate confirms it. Among the options, Terazosin is a first-line pharmacotherapy for BPH as it relaxes the prostate and bladder neck muscles to ease urination. Phenoxybenzamine is for hypertension caused by pheochromocytoma, Tamsulosin is also for BPH but is a second-line drug as it only targets α1A receptors, and α-Methyldopa is for hypertension but not for BPH.

Terazosin alpha-blockers are commonly used to treat BPH symptoms by relaxing the smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck. Phenoxybenzamine is used to treat hypertension caused by pheochromocytoma. Tamsulosin is also an alpha-blocker but is more selective for the prostate and would be another appropriate option. α-Methyldopa is primarily used as an antihypertensive and is not typically used to treat BPH symptoms.

Tamsulosin and terazosin are both alpha-blockers used to treat BPH, but terazosin is generally preferred in patients with hypertension as it can also lower blood pressure. Phenoxybenzamine is used for the treatment of hypertension caused by pheochromocytoma, and α-methyldopa is an antihypertensive medication that is not indicated for the treatment of BPH.

Terazosin is an alpha-blocker that can help relax the smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck and improve urine flow in patients with BPH. None of the other options are appropriate for BPH.
